sentence: A cell is the smallest unit of a living thing.
triplets: cell::is the smallest unit of::living thing

sentence: Whether comprised of one cell (like bacteria) or many cells (like a human), we call it an organism.
Thus, cells are the basic building blocks of all organisms.
triplets: Cells::are the basic building blocks of::all organisms

sentence: Several cells of one kind that interconnect with each other and perform a shared function form tissues.
These tissues combine to form an organ (your stomach, heart, or brain), and several organs comprise an organ system (such as the digestive system, circulatory system, or nervous system).
triplets: digestive system::is an example of::organ system
circulatory system::is an example of::organ system
nervous system::is an example of::organ system

sentence: Several systems that function together form an organism (like a human being).
Here, we will examine the structure and function of cells.
There are many types of cells, which scientists group into one of two broad categories: prokaryotic and eukaryotic.
For example, we classify both animal and plant cells as eukaryotic cells; whereas, we classify bacterial cells as prokaryotic.
Before discussing the criteria for determining whether a cell is prokaryotic or eukaryotic, we will first examine how biologists study cells.
Cells vary in size.
With few exceptions, we cannot see individual cells with the naked eye, so scientists use microscopes (micro- = "small"; -scope = "to look at") to study them.
A microscope is an instrument that magnifies an object.
We photograph most cells with a microscope, so we can call these images micrographs.
The optics of a microscope's lenses change the image orientation that the user sees.
A specimen that is right-side up and facing right on the microscope slide will appear upside-down and facing left when one views through a microscope, and vice versa.
triplets: specimen::is positioned::right-side up and facing right on the microscope slide
specimen::appears::upside-down and facing left when viewed through a microscope

sentence: Similarly, if one moves the slide left while looking through the microscope, it will appear to move right, and if one moves it down, it will seem to move up.
This occurs because microscopes use two sets of lenses to magnify the image.

Because of the manner by which light travels through the lenses, this two lens system produces an inverted image (binocular, or dissecting microscopes, work in a similar manner, but include an additional magnification system that makes the final image appear to be upright).
triplets: binocular or dissecting microscopes::work in::similar manner
binocular or dissecting microscopes::include::additional magnification system
additional magnification system::makes::final image appear to be upright

sentence: To give you a sense of cell size, a typical human red blood cell is about eight millionths of a meter or eight micrometers (abbreviated as eight μm) in diameter.
triplets: human red blood cell::has diameter::eight millionths of a meter or eight micrometers

sentence: A pin head is about two thousandths of a meter (two mm) in diameter.
triplets: pin head::has diameter::two thousandths of a meter

sentence: That means about 250 red blood cells could fit on a pinhead.
Most student microscopes are light microscopes (Figure 4.2a).
Visible light passes and bends through the lens system to enable the user to see the specimen.
triplets: the lens system::enables::the user to see the specimen

sentence: Light microscopes are advantageous for viewing living organisms, but since individual cells are generally transparent, their components are not distinguishable unless they are colored with special stains.
triplets: Light microscopes::are advantageous for viewing::living organisms
Components of cells::are not distinguishable unless colored with::special stains

sentence: Staining, however, usually kills the cells.
Light microscopes that undergraduates commonly use in the laboratory magnify up to approximately 400 times.
triplets: Light microscopes::commonly used by::undergraduates in the laboratory

sentence: Two parameters that are important in microscopy are magnification and resolving power.
Magnification is the process of enlarging an object in appearance.
triplets: Magnification::is the process of::enlarging an object in appearance

sentence: Resolving power is the microscope's ability to distinguish two adjacent structures as separate: the higher the resolution, the better the image's clarity and detail.
triplets: Resolving power::is the ability to distinguish::two adjacent structures as separate
resolution::is higher in::better image's clarity and detail

sentence: When one uses oil immersion lenses to study small objects, magnification usually increases to 1,000 times.
triplets: oil immersion lenses::used to study::small objects

sentence: In order to gain a better understanding of cellular structure and function, scientists typically use electron microscopes.
triplets: scientists::gain understanding of::cellular structure and function

sentence: a) Most light microscopes in a college biology lab can magnify cells up to approximately 400 times and have a resolution of about 200 nanometers.
triplets: Most light microscopes in a college biology lab::can magnify::cells up to approximately 400 times
Most light microscopes in a college biology lab::have::a resolution of about 200 nanometers

sentence: b) Electron microscopes provide a much higher magnification, 100,000x, and a have a resolution of 50 picometers.
use a beam of electrons instead of a beam of light.
triplets: beam of electrons::can be used instead of::beam of light

sentence: Not only does this allow for higher magnification and, thus, more detail (Figure 4.3), it also provides higher resolving power.
triplets: this::allow for::higher magnification and more detail

sentence: The method to prepare the specimen for viewing with an electron microscope kills the specimen.
Electrons have short wavelengths (shorter than photons) that move best in a vacuum, so we cannot view living cells with an electron microscope.
triplets: We::cannot view::living cells with an electron microscope

sentence: In a scanning electron microscope, a beam of electrons moves back and forth across a cell's surface, creating details of cell surface characteristics.
triplets: movement of beam::creates::details of cell surface characteristics

sentence: In a transmission electron microscope, the electron beam penetrates the cell and provides details of a cell's internal structures.
triplets: transmission electron microscope::has electron beam::penetrates cell
electron beam::provides details of::cell's internal structures

sentence: As you might imagine, electron microscopes are significantly more bulky and expensive than light microscopes.
triplets: electron microscopes::are significantly more bulky and expensive than::light microscopes

sentence: a) These Salmonella bacteria appear as tiny purple dots when viewed with a light microscope.
b) This scanning electron microscope micrograph shows Salmonella bacteria (in red) invading human cells (yellow).
triplets: scanning electron microscope micrograph::show::Salmonella bacteria invading human cells

sentence: Even though subfigure (b) shows a different Salmonella specimen than subfigure (a), you can still observe the comparative increase in magnification and detail.
triplets: you::can observe::the comparative increase in magnification and detail

sentence: For another perspective on cell size, try the HowBig interactive at this site.
The microscopes we use today are far more complex than those that Dutch shopkeeper Antony van Leeuwenhoek, used in the 1600s.
triplets: The microscopes::are more complex than::those that Dutch shopkeeper Antony van Leeuwenhoek used in the 1600s

sentence: Skilled in crafting lenses, van Leeuwenhoek observed the movements of single-celled organisms, which he collectively termed "animalcules."
In the 1665 publication Micrographia, experimental scientist Robert Hooke coined the term "cell" for the box-like structures he observed when viewing cork tissue through a lens.
In the 1670s, van Leeuwenhoek discovered bacteria and protozoa.
Later advances in lenses, microscope construction, and staining techniques enabled other scientists to see some components inside cells.
triplets: Later advances in lenses::enabled scientists to see::some components inside cells
Microscope construction::enabled scientists to see::some components inside cells
Staining techniques::enabled scientists to see::some components inside cells

sentence: By the late 1830s, botanist Matthias Schleiden and zoologist Theodor Schwann were studying tissues and proposed the unified cell theory, which states that one or more cells comprise all living things, the cell is the basic unit of life, and new cells arise from existing cells.
triplets: unified cell theory::states::one or more cells comprise all living things
unified cell theory::states::the cell is the basic unit of life
unified cell theory::states::new cells arise from existing cells

sentence: Rudolf Virchow later made important contributions to this theory.
Have you ever heard of a medical test called a Pap smear (Figure 4.4)?

In this test, a doctor takes a small sample of cells from the patient's uterine cervix and sends it to a medical lab where a cytotechnologist stains the cells and examines them for any changes that could indicate cervical cancer or a microbial infection.
triplets: doctor::takes::small sample of cells from patient's uterine cervix
changes in cells::indicate::cervical cancer or microbial infection

sentence: Cytotechnologists (cyto- = "cell") are professionals who study cells via microscopic examinations and other laboratory tests.
They are trained to determine which cellular changes are within normal limits and which are abnormal.
triplets: They::are trained to determine::which cellular changes are within normal limits
They::are trained to determine::which cellular changes are abnormal

sentence: Their focus is not limited to cervical cells.
They study cellular specimens that come from all organs.
When they notice abnormalities, they consult a pathologist, a medical doctor who interprets and diagnoses changes that disease in body tissue and fluids cause.
triplets: pathologist::interprets and diagnoses::changes that disease in body tissue and fluids cause

sentence: Cytotechnologists play a vital role in saving people's lives.
triplets: Cytotechnologists::play a vital role in::saving people's lives

sentence: When doctors discover abnormalities early, a patient's treatment can begin sooner, which usually increases the chances of a successful outcome.
triplets: early discovery of abnormalities::allow for::earlier treatment

sentence: These uterine cervix cells, viewed through a light microscope, are from a Pap smear.
Normal cells are on the left.
The cells on the right are infected with human papillomavirus (HPV).
triplets: cells on the right::are infected with::human papillomavirus

sentence: Notice that the infected cells are larger.
Also, two of these cells each have two nuclei instead of one, the normal number.
